The tribunal is due to report in 2016.{{Cite web|url = http://www.pcacases.com/web/sendAttach/1524|title = Arbitration between the Republic of the Philippines and the People's Republic of China|date = 30 November 2015|access-date = 14 February 2016|website = PCA Case Repository|publisher = [[Permanent Court of Arbitration]]|type = Press Release}} * 14 November – [[Indonesia]] announces that it is planning to take China to court over the [[Natuna Islands]].{{cite news|last1=Daiss|first1=Tim|title=Indonesia Ups The Ante In Disputed South China Sea, Oil And Gas Lurks In The Background |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/timdaiss/2015/11/12/indonesia-ups-the-ante-in-disputed-south-china-sea-oil-and-gas-lurks-in-the-background/|work=Forbes|date=12 November 2015}} * 31 December – China's Ministry of National Defense confirmed that they are building their second aircraft carrier. China's second aircraft carrier was being built in [[Dalian]], a port city located in northeastern China according to Col. Yang Yujun, a spokesman from the [[Ministry of National Defense of the People's Republic of China|Ministry of National Defense]].{{cite web|title=China will be having a second aircraft carrier, this time it's Made In China|url=http://www.manilalivewire.com/2016/01/china-will-be-having-a-second-aircraft-carrier-this-time-its-made-in-china/|work=Manila Livewire|accessdate=22 May 2016|date=1 January 2016}} === 2016 === * 3 January – Vietnamese Foreign Ministry spokesperson Le Hai Binh said that the landing of a civilian aircraft in [[Fiery Cross Reef]] is "a serious infringement of the sovereignty of Vietnam on the Spratly archipelago".{{cite web|last1=Panda|first1=Ankit|title=Vietnam Protests as China Lands Civilian Aircraft on Newly Constructed Spratly Airstrip|url=http://thediplomat.com/2016/01/vietnam-protests-as-china-lands-civilian-aircraft-on-newly-constructed-spratly-airstrip/|work=The Diplomat|accessdate=22 May 2016|date=3 January 2016}} * 13 January – China has finished construction on a 10,000-ton cutter destined for patrols in the South China Sea.{{cite web|last1=Gady|first1=Franz-Stefan|title=Beijing Builds 'Monster' Ship for Patrolling the South China Sea|url=http://thediplomat.com/2016/01/beijing-builds-monster-ship-for-patrolling-the-south-china-sea/|work=The Diplomat|accessdate=22 May 2016|date=13 January 2016}} * 13 February – Satellite images shows that China is currently expanding the North Island and Tree Island, both part of the [[Paracel Islands]]. Water capture reservoirs and fuel bunkers are the newly constructed structures seen in Fiery Cross Reef. A newly visible helicopter base is under construction in Duncan Island suggesting that Beijing may develop a network of bases in the South China Sea to support anti-submarine helicopters.{{cite web|last1=Lee|first1=Victor|title=Satellite Imagess: China Manufactures Land at New Sites in the Paracel Islands|url=http://thediplomat.com/2016/02/satellite-images-china-manufactures-land-at-new-sites-in-the-paracel-islands/|work=The Diplomat|accessdate=22 May 2016|date=13 February 2016}} * 22 February – Japanese Foreign Minister [[Fumio Kishida]] cancels his plans to visit China.{{cite web|last1=Panda|first1=Ankit|title=Japan's Foreign Minister Cancels Plans to Visit China|url=http://thediplomat.com/2016/02/japans-foreign-minister-cancels-plans-to-visit-china/|work=The Diplomat|accessdate=22 May 2016|date=22 February 2016}} * 14 March – Beijing will set-up an International Maritime Judicial Center similar to the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS) in order to help protect every countries sea rights. According to Chief justice [[Zhou Qiang]], the Chinese judicial center will primarily focus on the case of countries with territorial issues with China.{{cite web|title=China Sea territorial disputes to be handled by International Maritime Judicial Center created by Beijing|url=http://www.manilalivewire.com/2016/03/china-sea-territorial-disputes-to-be-handled-by-international-maritime-judicial-center-created-by-beijing/|work=Manila Livewire|accessdate=22 May 2016|date=14 March 2016}} * 19 March – Indonesian maritime official involved in a clash with a Chinese coast guard boat over a Chinese trawler accused for illegal fishing off the Natuna islands. Chinese fishermen were under Indonesia's custody, while the trawler was set free after being rammed by Chinese coast guard boat.{{cite news | title = Indonesia to Summon Chinese Ambassador Over Natuna Islands Standoff | date = 21 March 2016 | newspaper = The Jakarta Globe | url = http://jakartaglobe.beritasatu.com/news/indonesia-summon-chinese-ambassador-standoff-natuna-islands/}} * 5 April – China has started to operate a new lighthouse in Subi Reef.{{cite web|title=China started to operate a Lighthouse on a Fake Island in the West Philippine Sea|url=http://www.manilalivewire.com/2016/04/china-started-to-operate-a-lighthouse-on-a-fake-island-in-the-west-philippine-sea/|work=Manila Livewire|accessdate=24 May 2016|date=7 April 2016}} * 22 April – Four [[Fairchild Republic A-10 Thunderbolt II|A-10 Thunderbolt]] and two [[Sikorsky HH-60 Pave Hawk|HH-60G Pave Hawks]] based in [[Clark Air Base]] conducted flying operations in the vicinity of Scarborough Shoal.{{cite web|last1=Mangosing|first1=Frances|title=US warplanes in Clark conduct fly ops on Scarborough Shoal|url=http://globalnation.inquirer.net/138846/us-warplanes-in-clark-conduct-fly-ops-in-scarborough-shoal|work=Inquirer|accessdate=23 May 2016|date=22 April 2016}} * 10 May – China's navy has launched annual war drills in the South China Sea with one of its most advanced warships. The exercises include simulations for breaking an enemy blockade and reconnaissance drills with submarine forces.{{cite web|title=South China Sea watch: China starts drills, showcases isles|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2016/05/10/1581789/south-china-sea-watch-china-starts-drills-showcases-isles|work=The Philippine Star|accessdate=22 May 2016|date=10 May 2016}} * 10 May – The [[USS William P. Lawrence]] sailed within 12 miles of Fiery Cross Reef as part of the freedom of navigation patrol.{{cite web|last1=Perlez|first1=Jane|title=U.S. Sails Warship Near Island in South China Sea, Challenging Chinese Claims|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/11/world/asia/south-china-sea-us-warship.html|work=The New York Times|accessdate=22 May 2016|date=10 May 2016}} * 10 May – China scrambled two fighter jets and three warships as the USS William P. Lawrence sailed within 12 nautical miles of Fiery Cross Reef.{{cite web|last1=Martina|first1=Michael|last2=Torode|first2=Greg|last3=Blanchard|first3=Ben|title=China scrambles fighters as U.S. sails warship near Chinese-claimed reef|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-southchinasea-usa-china-idUSKCN0Y10DM|agency=Reuters|accessdate=22 May 2016|date=10 May 2016}} * 13 May – [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the People's Republic of China|Chinese Foreign Ministry]] spokeswoman [[Hua Chunying]] said that more than 40 countries support its stance on South China Sea dispute.{{cite web|last1=Rajagopalan|first1=Megha|title=China says more than 40 countries support its stance on South China Sea dispute|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-southchinasea-china-idUSKCN0YB1EO|agency=Reuters|accessdate=22 May 2016|date=20 May 2016}} * 17 May – Two [[Shenyang J-11]] fighter jets intercepted a US Navy [[Lockheed EP-3|E-P3]] military reconnaissance aircraft flying in international airspace over the South China Sea.{{cite web|last1=Kube|first1=Courtney|title=Chinese Intercept U.S. Military Spy Plane Over South China Sea|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/china/chinese-intercept-u-s-military-spy-plane-over-south-china-n576351|accessdate=22 May 2016|date=18 May 2016}} * 19 May – Indonesian military General Gatot Nurmantyo says they are considering conducting joint patrols with Malaysia and Philippines.{{cite web|last1=Ismail|first1=Saifulbahri|title=Indonesia considering South China Sea patrols with Malaysia, Philippines: Military chief|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/asiapacific/indonesia-considering/2799990.html|publisher=Channel NewsAsia|accessdate=23 May 2016|date=19 May 2016}} * 20 May – The USS John Stennis Strike Group patrolling the South China Sea visits Philippines.{{cite web|last1=Mangosing|first1=Frances|title=US strike group patrolling in South China Sea visits PH|url=http://globalnation.inquirer.net/139575/us-strike-group-patrolling-in-south-china-sea-visits-ph|work=Inquirer|accessdate=23 May 2016|date=20 May 2016}} * 21 May – China objects to the presence of four Indian ships in the South China Sea. The ships sailed on Wednesday for a two-and-a-half month long operational deployment to the SCS and North West Pacific. The ships will also take part in the Malabar exercise in the waters of the Philippines.{{cite web|last1=Chaudhury|first1=Dipanjan|title=China objects to presence of Indian ships in South China Sea|url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/defence/china-objects-to-presence-of-indian-ships-in-south-china-sea/articleshow/52369749.cms|work=The Economic Times|accessdate=23 May 2016|date=21 May 2016}} * 23 May – US President [[Barack Obama]] visits Vietnam aiming to strengthen bilateral ties.{{cite web|last1=Revesz|first1=Rachael|title=Obama to visit Vietnam amid escalating tensions over Chinese expansion in South China Sea|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/obama-to-visit-vietnam-amid-escalating-tensions-over-chinese-expansion-in-south-china-sea-a7042676.html|work=The Independent|accessdate=23 May 2016|date=23 May 2016}} * 23 May – A Chinese government bureau is planning to build a base station in the Spratly Islands to aid fishing boats in trouble and shorten the distance they need to travel.{{cite web|last1=Rajagopalan|first1=Megha|title=China plans base station for rescue operations in South China Sea|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-southchinasea-china-idUSKCN0YE0BL|agency=Reuters|accessdate=24 May 2016|date=23 May 2016}} * 23 June – Indonesian President [[Joko Widodo]] sailed on a warship off Natuna islands to send a "clear message that the nation was very serious in its effort to protect its sovereignty".{{cite news | title = South China Sea: Indonesian leader visits Natuna Islands amid growing tensions | date = 23 June 2016 | work = ABC News | url = http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-06-23/joko-widodo-visits-south-china-sea-amid-tension-with-china/7539164}} * 8 July – Philippine Foreign Secretary Perfecto Yasay said that the Philippines is willing to share the natural resources of West Philippine Sea to China.{{Cite web|url=http://www.rappler.com/nation/139069-philippines-share-south-china-sea|title=PH willing to share resources in West PH Sea|last=|first=|date=8 July 2016|website=Rappler|publisher=|access-date=15 July 2016}} * 12 July – A tribunal of [[Permanent Court of Arbitration]] rejects Chinese [[Nine-dash line]] historical claims over South China Sea, concluding it has no legal basis. The tribunal ruled against China in the ''[[Philippines v. China]]'' case, and unanimously award in favour of the Philippines.[https://pca-cpa.org/wp-content/uploads/sites/175/2016/07/PH-CN-20160712-Press-Release-No-11-English.pdf PCA Press Release 12 juli 2016, The South China Sea Arbitration (The Republic of the Philippines v. The People's Republic of China).]{{cite news | title = South China Sea: Court rules in favor of Philippines over China | author = Katie Hunt | date = 12 July 2016| work = CNN | url = http://edition.cnn.com/2016/07/12/asia/china-philippines-south-china-sea/}} * 12 July – Beijing promptly rejects the tribunal ruling and called it "void".{{cite news | work = The Guardian | title = Beijing rejects tribunal's ruling in South China Sea case | date = 12 July 2016 | url = https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/jul/12/philippines-wins-south-china-sea-case-against-china }} * 12 July – [[Ethiopia]] supports China's stance in the dispute.{{Cite web|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201607130705.html|title=Ethiopia Supports China's Stand On South China Sea|last=|first=|date=13 July 2016|website=All Africa|publisher=|access-date=15 July 2016}} * 25 July 2016 – in Vientiane, Laos, [[ASEAN]] issued a joint statement regarding South China Sea dispute, which stated their commitment to ensure and promote the peace, stability and security in the region.{{ cite web | title = Joint Statement of the Foreign Ministers of ASEAN Member States on the Maintenance of Peace, Security, and Stability in the Region | work = ASEAN.org | url = http://asean.org/joint-statement-of-the-foreign-ministers-of-asean-member-states-on-the-maintenance-of-peace-security-and-stability-in-the-region/}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} [[Category:South China Sea|timeline of territorial dispute]] [[Category:Politics-related lists]]

The '''Truth in Music Advertising''' act or bill, also known as '''Truth in Music Performance Advertising''' or simply '''Truth in Music''', is legislation, adopted into [[state law]] by most [[U.S. state]]s, that aims to protect the [[trademark]] of musical recording artists. The legislation provides that the name of a famous musical group cannot be used by a group of performers unless they include at least one member of the original group. The intent of the legislation is to prevent unfair or deceptive trade practices, and to protect the livelihood of musicians who were in famous musical groups.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://definitions.uslegal.com/t/truth-in-music-advertising-act/|title=Truth in Music Advertising Act Law and Legal Definition|website=definitions.uslegal.com}}</ref>
The legislation, co-authored by former [[Sha Na Na]] member [[Jon Bauman|Jon "Bowzer" Bauman]]<ref>{{cite web |url=https://bowzerparty.com/about |title=About Bowzer |work=Bowzer's Rock 'n' Roll Party |last=Bauman |first=Jon |authorlink=Jon Bauman |date=2017 |accessdate=July 9, 2017}}</ref> and promoted by him and [[Mary Wilson (singer)|Mary Wilson]] of [[the Supremes]], was not passed by the [[United States Congress|U.S. Congress]], but has been enacted in 34 of the 50 states.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/sdut-californian-bowzers-show-about-true-oldies-rock-2011mar16-story.html |title=Bowzer's show about true oldies rock and roll |agency=The Californian |last=Dail |first=Jim |date=March 16, 2011 |newspaper=The San Diego Union-Tribune }}</ref> The legislation has been tested in the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit|U.S. Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit]]. {{TOC limit|2}}
==Background== From 1977 to 1981, Jon "Bowzer" Bauman hosted other musicians on his television show [[Sha Na Na (TV series)|''Sha Na Na'']]. He talked with [[Carl Gardner]] of [[the Coasters]] and [[Charlie Thomas (musician)|Charlie Thomas]] of [[the Drifters]], discovering in the process that they were being victimized by "knock-off" groups of performers using the name of a famous group without having a member of that group. [[Ben E. King]] said he, Thomas and [[Bill Pinkney]] were losing out on potential gigs and income because there were "so many fake Drifters performing".<ref name="20/20 ABC News 2007">{{cite news |url=http://abcnews.go.com/2020/story?id=3914512&page=1 |title=Doo Wop Groups of the '50s and '60s Say 'Enough!' to Bogus Bands |work=[[20/20 (U.S. TV series)|20/20]] |publisher=ABC News |date=November 30, 2007 |last=Stossel |first=John |last2=Mastropolo |first2=Frank }}</ref> [[Herb Reed]] of [[the Platters]] told Bauman that his group had experienced "about 30" court cases fighting against fake groups. Researching the laws, Bauman found that the original musicians had scant legal protection against their group name being used by promoters or other performers, so he determined to amend the existing laws to increase protection for the original musicians. He allied with the [[Vocal Group Hall of Fame]] (VGHF) to bring famous musicians together to help promote these new laws.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.sharonherald.com/community/truth-in-music-crusade-gaining-steam/article_400c793b-7413-5bdb-a2bd-fdecc5cbeb42.html |title='Truth in Music' crusade gaining steam |last=Pinchot |first=Joe |date=August 16, 2006 |newspaper=The Herald |location=Sharon, Pennsylvania}}</ref> VGHF President Bob Crosby said of the fake groups "It's a form of identity theft to the artists... Most importantly it is misleading the public for them to think they are seeing the artist who made the hits when they are not."<ref name="Washington Times 2007">{{cite news |url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2007/feb/5/20070205-103606-5080r/ |title=Bill targets bogus bands using legendary names |author=Staff |date=February 5, 2007 |newspaper=Washington Times |location=Washington DC}}</ref> Mary Wilson of the Supremes joined the effort, appearing with Bauman before the US Congress in March 1999.<ref name="AP March 1999"/> She said "We want these fake groups to say they are tribute groups or get their own name."<ref>{{cite magazine |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4xUEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA45 |page=45 |last=Mitchell |first=Gail |title=Knocking Out the Knockoffs |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |volume=118 |number=19 |date=May 13, 2006 |issn=0006-2510 |publisher=Nielsen Business Media}}</ref>
==Lawsuits== [[The Drifters]] formed in 1953 with singer [[Clyde McPhatter]] and manager [[George Treadwell]] sharing the name equally. McPhatter sold his half to Treadwell in 1954, giving Treadwell full control of the Drifters' name, an action that he later regretted, because it caused financial problems for his fellow musicians.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/the-drifters-mn0000118544/biography|title=The Drifters - Biography & History - AllMusic|author=|date=|website=AllMusic|access-date=August 5, 2017}}</ref> Treadwell died in 1967, leaving his widow, Faye Treadwell, as manager of the group. In 1969, the founder and editor of ''Rock Magazine'', Larry Marshak, planned a series of concerts to be performed by classic vocal groups including the Drifters. Former Drifter Ben E. King responded that he would not perform, but he referred Marshak to Charlie Thomas, Elsbeary Hobbs and Doc Green, who agreed. Thomas, Hobbs and Green continued to perform as the Drifters under Marshak's management through the 1970s. However, starting in 1972, Faye Treadwell revived the Drifters in the UK. Faye Treadwell and Marshak sued each other several times over the rights to the group name, with Treadwell winning the rights to the Drifters name in July 1999, Judge [[Nicholas H. Politan]] presiding in the case ''Marshak v. Treadwell, et al''.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/08/22/nyregion/pop-music-there-are-oldies-and-there-are-new-oldies.html |title=There are Oldies, and There are New Oldies |last=Demaster |first=Karen |date=August 22, 1999 |newspaper=The New York Times}}</ref>
Marshak appealed the decision to the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit|Third Circuit]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://blog.timesunion.com/chuckmiller/the-drifters-a-legacy-of-harmony/26399/ |title=The Drifters: A Legacy of Harmony |last=Miller |first=Chuck |date=January 3, 2016 |newspaper=Times Union |publisher=The Hearst Corporation}} Originally published in [[Goldmine (magazine)|''Goldmine'']] magazine in 2000.</ref> Federal Judges [[Samuel Alito]], [[Maryanne Trump Barry]] and [[Ruggero J. Aldisert]] determined in February 2001 that Marshak's 1978 trademark registration for the Drifters name must be canceled as invalid, and that Marshak must stop using the Drifters' name in business. Marshak was ordered to tell the court how much money he had made on performances by the Drifters.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://caselaw.findlaw.com/us-3rd-circuit/1178360.html |title=Marshak v. Treadwell |date=February 9, 2001 |work=FindLaw |accessdate=July 9, 2017}}</ref>
After learning of Faye Treadwell's declining health, daughter Tina Treadwell left her position as vice president at Disney to continue the court battle, filing parallel lawsuits in the US and the UK in December 2006. Tina Treadwell said of Marshak and his associates, "They've diluted the brand with impostors."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2007/mar/15/local/me-drifters15 |title=Drifters sure get around |date=March 15, 2007 |last=Mitchell |first=John L. |newspaper=Los Angeles Times}}</ref> [[20/20 (U.S. TV series)|''20/20'']] reported in 2007 that promoters Charles Mehlich and Larry Marshak were being sued in New Jersey for using the Drifters' name.<ref name="20/20 ABC News 2007"/> Marshak, his associate Barry Singer, and their attorney William L. Charron countersued, charging that New Jersey's Attorney General [[Anne Milgram]] should not have issued subpoenas to the [[The Atlantic Club Casino Hotel|Atlantic City Hilton Casino]] in her effort to enforce the state's recently passed Truth in Music law, to stop performances by groups billed as the Platters, the Drifters and the Coasters. The countersuit was seen as the first legal challenge to the Truth in Music legislation.<ref>{{cite news |title=Oldies groups go to court to challenge 'truth in music' law |last=Porter |first=David |date=September 8, 2007 |agency=Associated Press}}</ref> In September 2007, U.S. District Judge [[Dickinson R. Debevoise]] found Marshak in [[contempt of court]] for continuing to use the group names after the 1999 injunction against him doing so. The court discovered that Marshak had employed business associates and his relatives to run legal entities which promoted concerts by the Platters, the Coasters and the Drifters despite having no original singers among the performers. Debevoise called this deceptive business practice "an elaborate shell game."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2007/sep/13/news/wk-quick13.s3 |title=Music promoter reprimanded |agency=Associated Press |date=September 13, 2007 |newspaper=Los Angeles Times}}</ref> Marshak appealed, but lost in July 2009.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.law360.com/articles/109589/3rd-circ-backs-drifters-ex-manager-in-trademark-suit |title=3rd Circ. Backs Drifters Ex-Manager In Trademark Suit |last=Davis |first=Ryan |date=July 2, 2009 |work=Law360 |location=New York City |accessdate=July 9, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.lexology.com/library/detail.aspx?g=992e7ba8-9f2a-4540-a3c5-2a3c1cbfba32 |title=Promoter must pay for enjoined drifting under the boardwalk |last=McDermott |first=Emery |date=July 27, 2009 |work=Lexology |publisher=Globe Business Media Group |accessdate=July 9, 2017}}</ref>
Barry Singer's business, Singer Management Consultants, was ordered to pay $24 million in damages, with $9 million going to Faye Treadwell, but Singer filed for personal bankruptcy under [[Chapter 7, Title 11, United States Code|Chapter 7]]. In September 2010, a federal appeals court determined that Singer must pay Treadwell regardless of his bankruptcy filing.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://fairlawn.dailyvoice.com/police-fire/broke-trademark-thief-still-on-the-hook-for-24m-to-the-drifters/629167/ |work=Fair Lawn-Glen Rock Daily Voice |title=Broke trademark thief still on the hook for $24M to the Drifters |last=DeMarco |first=Jerry |date=September 22, 2010 |location=New Jersey}}</ref> Faye Treadwell died in 2011.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/faye-treadwell-manager-drifters-dies-193900 |title=Faye Treadwell, Former Manager of the Drifters, Dies at 84 |date=June 1, 2011 |work=Hollywood Reporter |last=Barnes |first=Mike}}</ref>
The Truth in Music legislation was dealt a blow in August 2010 after a federal appeals court ordered the state of New Jersey to pay "significant" attorney's fees to Marshak and his associates.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.pressofatlanticcity.com/news/breaking/appeals-court-hands-new-jersey-a-defeat-in-truth-in/article_ce8a985e-a402-11df-8135-001cc4c002e0.html|title=Appeals court hands New Jersey a defeat in 'Truth in Music Law' case involving 'tribute' bands|newspaper=Press of Atlantic City|date=August 9, 2010|agency=Associated Press|publisher=BH Media Group}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.musiclawupdates.com/?p=1357 |work=Music Law Updates|title=Truth in Music laws take a knock in court setback}}</ref>
==Federal legislation== In March 1999, during the [[106th United States Congress|106th Congress]], Representative [[Dennis Kucinich]] introduced a "Truth in Rock" bill (H.R. 1125).<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=57zfDgAAQBAJ&pg=PT315 |pages=315–16 |title=Trademarks and Unfair Competition: Law and Policy |first=Graeme B. |last=Dinwoodie |first2=Mark D. |last2=Janis |publisher=Wolters Kluwer Law & Business |date=2013 |isbn=9781454843191}}</ref> Musicians Jon "Bowzer" Bauman testified in support of the bill before the [[United States House Judiciary Subcommittee on Courts, the Internet, and Intellectual Property|House Intellectual Property Subcommittee]]; Mary Wilson also lobbied for the legislation.<ref name="AP March 1999">{{cite news |author=AP staff |title=Hearings open on anti-impostor `Truth in Rock Act' |agency=Associated Press |date=March 16, 1999 |location=Washington, DC}}</ref><ref>[https://www.loc.gov/item/00326493/ Trademark Amendments Act of 1999]: hearing before the Subcommittee on Courts and Intellectual Property of the Committee on the Judiciary, House of Representatives, One Hundred Sixth Congress, first session, on H.R. 1565, May 5, 1999.</ref> The bill was intended "to amend the Trademark Act of 1946 to increase the penalties for infringing the rights pertaining to famous performing groups and to clarify the law pertaining to the rights of individuals who perform services as a group."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/HJOURNAL-1999/html/HJOURNAL-1999-03-16-para23-26.htm|title=Tuesday, March 16, 1999 (23), Para 23.26 Public Bills and Resolutions|website=www.gpo.gov}}</ref> The bill "died" (was not recommended for further action.)<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.govtrack.us/congress/bills/106/hr1125|title=To amend the Trademark Act of 1946 to increase the penalties for infringing the rights pertaining to famous performing groups and to clarify the law pertaining to the rights of individuals who perform services as a group. (1999 – H.R. 1125)|website=GovTrack.us}}</ref>
==Legislation by state== <!-- Chronological order by effective date --> ===Pennsylvania=== [[Pennsylvania]] was the first state to pass the legislation, doing so in October 2005,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://vocalgroup.org/truth-in-music/|title=The Vocal Group Hall Of Fame – Truth In Music|website=vocalgroup.org}}</ref> effective December 2005.
===Connecticut=== Sponsored by State Senator [[Andrew J. McDonald]], [[Connecticut]] passed the legislation as "An Act Concerning Truth in Music Advertising", effective July 1, 2006.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cga.ct.gov/2006/SUM/2006SUM00016-R01HB-05801-SUM.htm|title=An Act Concerning Truth in Music Advertising |first=Christopher|last=Reinhart|website=www.cga.ct.gov}}</ref>
===Illinois=== [[Illinois]] passed the law in 2006.<ref name=PEW2006>{{cite web|url=http://www.pewtrusts.org/en/research-and-analysis/blogs/stateline/2006/07/28/states-silence-musical-copycats|title=Stateline – States silence musical copycats|website=www.pewtrusts.org}}</ref>
===North Dakota=== [[North Dakota]] passed the law in 2006.<ref name=PEW2006/>
===South Carolina=== [[South Carolina]] passed the law in 2006<ref name=PEW2006/> as a new section of their existing chapter on unfair trade practices. The section is titled "Deceptive or misleading advertisement of live musical performance; injunction; penalty."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scstatehouse.gov/code/t39c005.php|title=Code of Laws – Title 39 – Chapter 5 – Unfair Trade Practices|website=www.scstatehouse.gov}}</ref>
===Massachusetts=== [[Massachusetts]] State Senator [[Marc R. Pacheco]] introduced the bill, which passed into law in 2006.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.patriotledger.com/x1262716133/MASS-MARKET-Truth-in-music-laws-keep-real-rock-rolling|title=Mass Market: ‘Truth in music’ laws keep real rock rolling|first=Jon|last=Chesto|publisher=}}</ref>
===Michigan=== [[Michigan]] State Senator [[Martha G. Scott]] introduced the bill in March 2006,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.michiganvotes.org/2006-SB-1125|title=2006 Senate Bill 1125: Regulate use of music group names|website=www.michiganvotes.org}}</ref> and it was debated in June.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://encore.celebrityaccess.com/index.php?encoreId=16&articleId=17359|title=ENCORE: The Standard in Live Entertainment News|website=encore.celebrityaccess.com|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060623051916/http://encore.celebrityaccess.com/index.php?encoreId=16&articleId=17359|archivedate=2006-06-23|df=}}</ref> It passed the State Senate in July,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.legislature.mi.gov/documents/2005-2006/billanalysis/Senate/htm/2005-SFA-1125-A.htm|title=1125: First Analysis (7-18-06) – Unfair Trade: Recording Group Name |website=www.legislature.mi.gov}}</ref> then the House in December. The law came in to effect on December 29, 2006, directly after being signed by Governor [[Jennifer Granholm]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.legislature.mi.gov/(S(qv1rqyzc0pdtv04qhfkpfvvp))/mileg.aspx?page=getobject&objectName=2006-SB-1125|title=Michigan Legislature – Senate Bill 1125 (2006)|website=www.legislature.mi.gov}}</ref>
===California=== As sponsored by State Senator [[Anthony Portantino]], [[California]] considered the legislation during early 2007, a state analyst noting that the proposed bill duplicated the protections already available under the state's existing unfair practices provisions, the 1872 [[California Unfair Competition Law]].<ref>ftp://leginfo.ca.gov/pub/07-08/bill/asm/ab_0701-0750/ab_702_cfa_20070416_131033_asm_comm.html</ref> Regardless, the Truth in Music Advertising Act was passed later in 2007, to come into effect on January 1, 2008.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.inta.org/INTABulletin/Pages/UNITEDSTATESCaliforniaTruthinMusicAdvertisingAct.aspx|title=California: Truth in Music Advertising Act|website=www.inta.org}}</ref>
===Virginia=== Introduced by Virginia Delegate [[David Albo]] who is also the leader of his band Planet Albo,<ref name="Washington Times 2007"/> [[Virginia]] passed the legislation after discussing it in January–February 2007.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://encore.celebrityaccess.com/index.php?encoreId=58&articleId=19855|title=ENCORE: The Standard in Live Entertainment News|website=encore.celebrityaccess.com}}{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.idolator.com/238393/virginia-legislation-would-make-fake-bands-even-more-reprehensible-than-usual|title=Virginia Legislation Would Make Fake Bands Even More Reprehensible Than Usual – idolator|date=21 February 2007|publisher=}}</ref>
===Tennessee=== [[Tennessee]] passed the legislation as "Tennessee Truth in Music Advertising Act", part of their Consumer Protection laws.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tn.gov/lawsandpolicies/topic/47-18-part-53-tennessee-truth-in-music-advertising-act|title=Title 47 Chapter 18 Part 53 Tennessee Truth in Music Advertising Act - TN.Gov|website=tn.gov|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161015124105/http://www.tn.gov/lawsandpolicies/topic/47-18-part-53-tennessee-truth-in-music-advertising-act|archivedate=2016-10-15|df=}}</ref> The bill, SB0262, became effective on May 30, 2007, upon the signature of the governor.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wapp.capitol.tn.gov/apps/Billinfo/default.aspx?BillNumber=SB0262&ga=105|title=Tennessee General Assembly » Legislation|website=wapp.capitol.tn.gov}}</ref>
===Florida=== [[Florida]] passed the legislation in June 2007; the State Senate passed the bill unanimously.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=7492256|title=Florida Eyes 'Truth in Music' Law|work=Morning Edition|publisher=NPR|date=February 20, 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theledger.com/news/20070421/truth-in-music-bill-passes-in-senate|title=Truth In Music Bill Passes in Senate|author=David Royse|agency=Associated Press|date=April 21, 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://cyberlaw.info/modules.php?op=modload&name=News&file=article&sid=81&theme=AutoPrint|title=Truth in Music Advertising Law|website=cyberlaw.info}}</ref>
===New Jersey=== [[New Jersey]] heard the proposed legislation in December 2006. The state passed the bill in May 2007.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://firemark.com/2007/05/14/new-jersey-joins-the-club-passes-a-truth-in-music-law/|title=New Jersey joins the club: passes a "Truth In Music" law. – Entertainment Law Offices of Gordon P. Firemark|publisher=}}</ref>
===Nevada=== [[Nevada]]'s Assembly passed the legislation unanimously in May 2007.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reviewjournal.com/news/politics-and-government/nevada/assembly-approves-truth-in-music-bill/|title=Assembly approves ‘Truth in Music’ bill|date=25 May 2007|publisher=}}</ref> After the Senate passed the bill, Governor [[Jim Gibbons (American politician)|Jim Gibbons]] signed it into law on May 31, 2007.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reviewjournal.com/news/politics-and-government/nevada/truth-in-music-bill-becomes-law/|title=Truth in Music bill becomes law|date=2 June 2007|publisher=}}</ref>
===Wisconsin=== Co-sponsored by State Senator [[Spencer Coggs]], [[Wisconsin]] heard arguments for the legislation in March 2007.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.shawanoleader.com/content/sha-na-na-member-support-bill-against-music-impostors|title=Sha Na Na member support bill against music impostors – The Shawano Leader|website=www.shawanoleader.com}}</ref> The Senate and Assembly passed the bill without debate in May.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wsaw.com/home/headlines/7426066.html|title=NEW INFO: Truth in Music Bill Backed by Sha Na Na Member Passes Legislature|agency=Associated Press}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://encore.celebrityaccess.com/index.php?encoreId=75&articleId=21499|title=ENCORE: The Standard in Live Entertainment News|website=encore.celebrityaccess.com}}{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Governor [[Jim Doyle]] signed the bill into law in July 2007.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wrn.com/2007/07/doyle-signs-truth-in-music-advertising-legislation/|title=Doyle signs truth in music advertising legislation|date=3 July 2007|publisher=}}</ref> The statute 100.185 is titled "Fraud, advertising musical performances."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://docs.legis.wisconsin.gov/statutes/statutes/100/185|title=Wisconsin Legislature: 100.185|website=Wisconsin Legislature}}</ref>
===Maine=== [[Maine]]'s State Representative Elaine Makas introduced the bill in February 2007. It passed in August 2007.<ref>https://www.sunjournal.com/node/516318{{dead link|date=February 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.lawserver.com/law/state/maine/me-statutes/maine_revised_statutes_title_10_1156|title=Maine Revised Statutes Title 10 Sec. 1156 – Short title – LawServer|publisher=}}</ref>
===New York=== Sponsored by State Senator [[John J. Flanagan]] and Assemblyman [[Peter M. Rivera]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://nypost.com/2007/06/18/doo-wops-demand-dont-wops/|title=DOO-WOPS DEMAND DON’T-WOPS|first=Kenneth|last=Lovett|date=18 June 2007|publisher=}}</ref> the state of [[New York (state)|New York]] passed the legislation, effective starting September 14, 2007.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gdnlaw.com/blog/internetlaw/2008/08/08/new-york-enacts-the-truth-in-music-advertising-act/|title=New York Enacts the Truth in Music Advertising Act – Internet Law Media Law Copyright and Trademark Law Blog|date=8 August 2008|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oregonlive.com/politics/index.ssf/2009/05/oregon_bill_targets_truth_in_m.html|title=Oregon bill targets "Truth in Music" for tribute bands|publisher=}}</ref>
===Indiana=== The [[Indiana House of Representatives]] voted unanimously to pass the bill in February 2008. State Representative [[Bruce Borders]], who is also an [[Elvis impersonator]], co-sponsored the legislation in the House.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indianahouserepublicans.com/news/press-releases/r45-borders-truth-in-music-advertising-bill-passes-house-2-28-2008/|title=[r45] Borders' Truth-in-Music-Advertising Bill Passes House (2/28/2008) – State of Indiana House of Representatives|website=www.indianahouserepublicans.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wthr.com/article/bills-address-domestic-violence-truth-music|title=Bills address domestic violence, truth in music|date=28 February 2008|publisher=}}</ref> State Senator [[Bob Deig]] sponsored the bill in the Senate, where it also passed. The bill was signed into law by Governor [[Mitch Daniels]] in March 2008.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.in.gov/archivecalendar/EventList.aspx?fromdate=1/1/2008&todate=12/31/2008&display=Month&type=public&eventidn=63256&view=EventDetails&information_id=127594|title=Governor signs Deig's 'truth in music advertising' legislation|publisher=}}</ref>
===Colorado=== [[Colorado]] heard arguments for the legislation in February 2008.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.coloradoindependent.com/3324/doo-wop-colorado-pol-on-truth-in-music-quest|title=Doo-Wop Colorado: Pol On 'Truth In Music' Quest|date=10 February 2008|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://coloradocapitoljournal.blogspot.com/2008/02/truth-in-music-bill-gets-committee-nod.html|title=Truth in Music Bill Gets Committee Nod|first=Hank|last=Lacey|date=11 February 2008|publisher=}}</ref> The bill was passed in April 2008.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.greeleytribune.com/news/local/greeley-man-helps-pass-truth-in-music-law/|title=Greeley man helps pass Truth in Music law - GreeleyTribune.com|website=www.greeleytribune.com}}</ref> The law was revised in 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://law.justia.com/codes/colorado/2016/title-6/fair-trade-and-restraint-of-trade/article-1/part-7/section-6-1-719|title=2016 Colorado Revised Statutes :: Title 6 – :: Consumer and Commercial Affairs :: Fair Trade and Restraint of Trade :: Article 1 – Colorado Consumer Protection Act :: Part 7 – :: Specific Provisions :: § 6-1-719. Truth in music advertising|publisher=}}</ref>
===Minnesota=== [[Minnesota]] debated the legislation in March 2007.<ref>http://www.house.leg.state.mn.us/hinfo/swkly/2007-08/sw1207.pdf</ref> The bill became law effective August 2008.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://locklaw.com/assets/newlaws_aug2008.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2017-07-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090106112042/http://www.locklaw.com/assets/newlaws_aug2008.pdf |archivedate=2009-01-06 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.mprnews.org/newscut/2008/07/sha_na_now/|title=The way we Sha Na Now|first=Tim|last=Nelson|publisher=}}</ref>
===Ohio=== [[Ohio]]'s State Senator [[Bob Schuler]] introduced the bill in January 2008.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://thebellwetherdaily.blogspot.com/2008/01/ohio-state-sen-bob-schuler-wants-truth.html|title=The Daily Bellwether: Ohio State Sen. Bob Schuler: Wants Truth In Concert Ads About 'Impostor Bands'|first=Bill|last=Sloat|date=3 January 2008|publisher=}}</ref> The bill was signed into law in January 2009 by Governor [[Ted Strickland]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.toledoblade.com/Music-Theater-Dance/2009/01/18/Under-new-Ohio-law-bands-claiming-to-be-classic-acts-must-have-an-original-member.html|title=Under new Ohio law, bands claiming to be classic acts must have an original member|date=17 January 2009|publisher=}}</ref>
===Oklahoma=== Introduced by State Representative [[Mike Thompson (Oklahoma politician)|Mike Thompson]], [[Oklahoma]] passed the bill in February 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pollstar.com/article/oklahoma-signs-truth-in-music-12573|title=Oklahoma Signs Truth In Music|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://encore.celebrityaccess.com/index.php?encoreId=175&articleId=29608|title=ENCORE: The Standard in Live Entertainment News|website=encore.celebrityaccess.com}}{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
===Arkansas=== [[Arkansas]] passed the legislation in March 2009.<ref>http://www.arkleg.state.ar.us/assembly/2009/R/Bills/HB2207.pdf</ref>
===Utah=== Sponsored by Reprentative [[Greg Hughes]], [[Utah]]'s House passed the bill unanimously in March 2009 as "Truth in Music".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://archive.sltrib.com/story.php?ref=/ci_11873465|title=Bowzer lobbies for Truth in Music bill|publisher=}}</ref> The Senate passed it, then Governor [[Jon Huntsman Jr.]] signed it into law on March 23, 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://trackbill.com/bill/ut-hb457-truth-in-music/379282/|title=HB457 – Utah 2009 – Truth in Music – TrackBill|website=trackbill.com}}</ref>
===Rhode Island=== Co-sponsored by State Representative Peter Petrarca and State Senator John J. Tassoni Jr, [[Rhode Island]] heard arguments for the legislation in March 2008, the bill titled "An Act Relating to Businesses and Professions – Musical Advertising." In June, the Senate passed the bill unanimously.<ref>http://webserver.rilin.state.ri.us/Journals08/SenateJournals08/SJournal6-18.pdf</ref> The bill became law in 2008.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://law.justia.com/codes/rhode-island/2013/title-5/chapter-5-81/section-5-81-1/|title=2013 Rhode Island General Laws :: Title 5 – Businesses and Professions :: Chapter 5–81 – Truth in Music Advertising Act :: Section 5-81-1 – Short title.|publisher=}}</ref>
===Delaware=== [[Delaware]] considered the bill in March 2006 but it died in committee in June that year.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://legis.delaware.gov/BillDetail/16653|title=Bill Detail – Delaware General Assembly|first=Delaware|last=Legislature|website=legis.delaware.gov}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://phoenix.state.de.us/LIS/lis143.nsf/93487d394bc01014882569a4007a4cb7/e1616b2631cd28c98525712b0056d73e?OpenDocument|title=www.legis.delaware.gov – Official web site of First State Legislature|website=phoenix.state.de.us}}</ref> The bill was discussed again in 2007–2008 and was signed into law July 2008, effective September 10, 2008.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://delcode.delaware.gov/sessionlaws/ga144/chp337.shtml|title=CHAPTER 337|website=delcode.delaware.gov}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://legis.delaware.gov/BillDetail/18417|title=Bill Detail – Delaware General Assembly|first=Delaware|last=Legislature|website=legis.delaware.gov}}</ref>
===New Mexico=== [[New Mexico]]'s State Representative [[Al Park]] sponsored the bill which was passed by the House in March 2009.<ref name=Roundhouse2009>{{cite web|url=http://roundhouseroundup.blogspot.com/2009/03/roundhouse-roundup-truth-in-music-act.html|title=ROUNDHOUSE ROUNDUP: THE BLOG: Roundhouse Roundup: The Truth in Music Act|first=Steve|last=Terrell|date=12 March 2009|publisher=}}</ref>
===North Carolina=== Sponsored by State Senator [[David F. Weinstein]], [[North Carolina]] passed the legislation in 2009.<ref>http://www.ncleg.net/Sessions/2009/Bills/Senate/PDF/S634v6.pdf</ref> The bill was titled "An Act to Prohibit the Advertising and Conducting of Certain Live Musical Performances or Productions, to Provide for Enforcement, and to Impose a Penalty."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ncleg.net/Sessions/2009/Bills/Senate/HTML/S634v0.html|title=S634 [Filed]|website=www.ncleg.net}}</ref>
===Washington=== Sponsored by [[Karen Keiser]], [[Washington (US state)|Washington]] considered the legislation during February–April 2009, with both the Senate and the House voting unanimously to pass the bill. On April 16, 2009, the bill was signed into law by Governor [[Christine Gregoire]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://app.leg.wa.gov/billsummary?BillNumber=5284&Year=2009 |title=Bill Information: SB 5284 – 2009–2010 – Concerning truth in music advertising. |publisher=Washington State Legislature }}</ref>
===New Hampshire=== Co-sponsored in the House by State Representatives [[Jackie Cilley]] and Robert "Bob" Perry, and in the Senate by State Senator Matthew Houde, [[New Hampshire]] heard arguments for the legislation in April 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.seacoastonline.com/article/20090421/News/90421031|title=Sha Na Na's 'Bowzer' testifies in N.H. for bill|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://localrhythms.wordpress.com/category/19511377/|title=19511377|website=localrhythms.wordpress.com}}</ref> Titled "An Act prohibiting the advertising and conducting of certain live musical performances or productions", the bill was signed into law in August 2009, to become effective on January 1, 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nhliberty.org/bills/view/2009/SB130|title=SB130 (2009) – New Hampshire Liberty Alliance|website=www.nhliberty.org|access-date=2017-07-09|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170802164939/https://www.nhliberty.org/bills/view/2009/SB130#|archive-date=2017-08-02|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
===Oregon=== [[Oregon]] passed the legislation in 2009, the effective date set at January 1, 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://olis.leg.state.or.us/liz/2009R1/Measures/Overview/SB464|title=Oregon Legislative Information System|website=olis.leg.state.or.us}}</ref>
===Maryland=== [[Maryland]] heard State Senator [[Michael G. Lenett]] introduce the bill in February 2008,<ref>http://mlis.state.md.us/2008rs/fnotes/bil_0001/sb0711.pdf</ref> and passed the legislation in 2010 as the "Truth in Music Advertising Act".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://law.justia.com/codes/maryland/2010/commercial-law/title-11/subtitle-15|title=2010 Maryland Code :: COMMERCIAL LAW :: TITLE 11 – TRADE REGULATION :: Subtitle 15 – Truth in Music Advertising Act|publisher=}}</ref>
===Kansas=== [[Kansas]] heard arguments for the legislation in February 2009, with Jon "Bowzer" Bauman appearing before the lawmakers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pitch.com/music/article/20585113/jon-bowzer-bauman-of-sha-na-na-convinces-kansas-to-pass-truth-in-musical-performance-advertising-act|title=Jon "Bowzer" Bauman of Sha Na Na Convinces Kansas to Pass "Truth in Musical Performance Advertising Act"|publisher=}}</ref> The bill was passed in 2010 as the "Truth in musical performance advertising act."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kslegislature.org/li_2014/b2013_14/statute/050_000_0000_chapter/050_006_0000_article/050_006_0116_section/050_006_0116_k/|title=Statute – Kansas State Legislature|website=www.kslegislature.org}}</ref><ref>http://www.kansas.gov/government/legislative/sessionlaws/2010/chap129.pdf</ref>
===Mississippi=== [[Mississippi]] passed the law in 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://law.justia.com/codes/mississippi/2010/title-75/91/|title=2010 Mississippi Code :: TITLE 75 – REGULATION OF TRADE, COMMERCE AND INVESTMENTS :: :: Chapter 91 – Truth in Music Advertising.|publisher=}}</ref>
===Georgia=== Sponsored by State Senator John "Dick" Crosby, [[Georgia (US state)|Georgia]] considered the legislation during March 2009,<ref>http://savannahnow.com/2009-03-05/bill-seeks-guarantee-truth-music#</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://savannahnow.com/2009-03-05/bill-seeks-guarantee-truth-music|title=Bill seeks to guarantee 'truth in music'|publisher=}}</ref><ref>http://onlineathens.com/multimedia/pdfs/2009/030609_sb226.pdf{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }}</ref> but the bill died in chamber.<ref>https://legiscan.com/GA/bill/SB226/2009</ref> In April 2010 the bill was recommended for further action.<ref>https://legiscan.com/GA/bill/SB226/2009</ref> The bill passed in 2014.
===Not enacted=== [[Alabama]] considered the legislation in early 2008,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailyreportonline.com/id=1202552325330/Alabama-Legislature-may-silence-impostor-performers?slreturn=20170608003626|title=Alabama Legislature may silence impostor performers|publisher=}}</ref> and again in early 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://legiscan.com/AL/bill/SB31/2010|title=Alabama SB31 – 2010 – Regular Session|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://legiscan.com/AL/comments/SB31/2010|title=Alabama SB31 – 2010 – Regular Session|publisher=}}</ref> The bill died in chamber. [[Alaska]], [[Arizona]], [[Hawaii]], [[Idaho]], [[Iowa]], [[Kentucky]], [[Louisiana]], [[Missouri]], [[Montana]], [[Nebraska]], [[South Dakota]], [[Texas]], [[Vermont]], [[West Virginia]] and [[Wyoming]] have not passed the legislation.<!-- The number of states passing the bill is 34 out of 50, so per WP:CALC the number of states not passing the bill is obviously 16. This section lists the 16 for convenience. -->
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== *[http://vocalgroup.org/truth-in-music/ Truth in Music] at Vocal Group Hall of Fame [[Category:United States state legislation]] [[Category:Trademark legislation]] [[Category:Consumer protection legislation]]

page.title: UNCITRAL Model Law on International Commercial Arbitration

revision.text:
{{Redirect|UNCITRAL Model Law|the cross-border insolvency regime|UNCITRAL Model Law on Cross-Border Insolvency}}
The '''UNCITRAL Model Law on International Commercial Arbitration'''<ref>[http://www.uncitral.org/uncitral/en/uncitral_texts/arbitration.html]</ref> was prepared by [[UNCITRAL]], and adopted by the United Nations Commission on International Trade Law on 21 June 1985. In 2006 the model law was amended, it now includes more detailed provisions on interim measures.
The model law is not binding, but individual states may adopt the model law by incorporating it into their domestic law (as, for example, [[Australia]] did, in the International Arbitration Act 1974, as amended).<ref>[http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/legis/cth/consol_act/iaa1974276/]</ref>
The model law was published in English and in French. Translations in all six United Nations languages now exist.<ref>http://www.uncitral.org/uncitral/en/uncitral_texts/arbitration/1985Model_arbitration.html</ref>
Note that there is a difference between the UNCITRAL ''Model Law'' on International Commercial Arbitration (1985) and the UNCITRAL ''Arbitration Rules''.<ref>[http://www.uncitral.org/uncitral/en/uncitral_texts/arbitration.html]</ref> On its website, UNCITRAL explains the difference as follows: "The UNCITRAL Model Law provides a pattern that law-makers in national governments can adopt as part of their domestic legislation on arbitration. The UNCITRAL Arbitration Rules, on the other hand, are selected by parties either as part of their contract, or after a dispute arises, to govern the conduct of an arbitration intended to resolve a dispute or disputes between themselves. Put simply, the Model Law is directed at States, while the Arbitration Rules are directed at potential (or actual) parties to a dispute."<ref>[http://www.uncitral.org/uncitral/en/uncitral_texts/arbitration_faq.html]</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.uncitral.org/pdf/english/texts/arbitration/ml-arb/06-54671_Ebook.pdf Text of the model law] ([[Portable Document Format|PDF]])
